abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Horn of Africa Emergency
            Health and Nutrition Project for Africa were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            high; Bank performance was satisfactory and borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            includes: ensuring a quick disbursing mechanism and working
            through specialized partner agencies for an effective
            emergency response. Need for speed and flexibility when
            responding to an emergency context. The speed, flexibility,
            and responsiveness with which the project was prepared,
            reflected the urgency and severity of the 2011 crisis in the
            Horn of Africa. The inclusion of retroactive financing in
            the project design encouraged and enabled rapid
            implementation start-up in the emergency response context.
            Utilizing standard International Development Association
            (IDA) lending instruments in support of refugee populations
            generally does not provide appealing options to governments.
            Importance of addressing the needs of refugee camps
            populations and surrounding communities in an integrated
            manner. Regional operations have an added benefit of
            addressing hard to reach communities.
